questions.question: ABC is an isosceles triangle with AB = AC and BD and CE are its two medians. Show that BD = CE.
questions.solution:
Given: $\triangle ABC$ is isosceles with $AB = AC$. $BD$ and $CE$ are medians.
To prove: $BD = CE$.
Proof:
Since $AB = AC$, we have $\frac{1}{2}AB = \frac{1}{2}AC$.
Since $BD$ and $CE$ are medians, $E$ is the midpoint of $AB$ and $D$ is the midpoint of $AC$.
Therefore, $AE = AD$.
In $\triangle ABD$ and $\triangle ACE$:
$AB = AC$ (Given)
$\angle A = \angle A$ (Common)
$AD = AE$ (Proved above)
$\therefore \triangle ABD \cong \triangle ACE$ (by SAS congruence rule).
$\Rightarrow BD = CE$ (by CPCT).

questions.question: In Fig. 7.4, D and E are points on side BC of a $\triangle ABC$ such that BD = CE and AD = AE. Show that $\triangle ABD \cong \triangle ACE$.
questions.solution:
Given: $BD = CE$ and $AD = AE$.
To prove: $\triangle ABD \cong \triangle ACE$.
Proof:
In $\triangle ADE$, since $AD = AE$, $\triangle ADE$ is an isosceles triangle.
$\therefore \angle ADE = \angle AED$ (Angles opposite to equal sides are equal).
Now, $\angle ADB + \angle ADE = 180^\circ$ (Linear pair)
$\angle AEC + \angle AED = 180^\circ$ (Linear pair)
$\Rightarrow \angle ADB = 180^\circ - \angle ADE$
$\Rightarrow \angle AEC = 180^\circ - \angle AED$
Since $\angle ADE = \angle AED$, we have $\angle ADB = \angle AEC$.
In $\triangle ABD$ and $\triangle ACE$:
$AD = AE$ (Given)
$\angle ADB = \angle AEC$ (Proved above)
$BD = CE$ (Given)
$\therefore \triangle ABD \cong \triangle ACE$ (by SAS congruence rule).

questions.question: CDE is an equilateral triangle formed on a side CD of a square ABCD (Fig. 7.5). Show that $\triangle ADE \cong \triangle BCE$.
questions.solution:
Given: $ABCD$ is a square and $CDE$ is an equilateral triangle.
To prove: $\triangle ADE \cong \triangle BCE$.
Proof:
Since $ABCD$ is a square, $AD = BC$ and $\angle ADC = \angle BCD = 90^\circ$.
Since $\triangle CDE$ is equilateral, $DE = CE = CD$ and $\angle CDE = \angle DCE = 60^\circ$.
Also, $CD = AD = BC$ (Sides of a square).
So, $DE = CE$.
Now, $\angle ADE = \angle ADC + \angle CDE = 90^\circ + 60^\circ = 150^\circ$.
$\angle BCE = \angle BCD + \angle DCE = 90^\circ + 60^\circ = 150^\circ$.
$\therefore \angle ADE = \angle BCE$.
In $\triangle ADE$ and $\triangle BCE$:
$AD = BC$ (Sides of square)
$\angle ADE = \angle BCE$ (Proved above)
$DE = CE$ (Sides of equilateral triangle)
$\therefore \triangle ADE \cong \triangle BCE$ (by SAS congruence rule).

questions.question: In Fig. 7.6, BA $\perp$ AC, DE $\perp$ DF such that BA = DE and BF = EC. Show that $\triangle ABC \cong \triangle DEF$.
questions.solution:
Given: $BA \perp AC$, $DE \perp DF$, $BA = DE$, and $BF = EC$.
To prove: $\triangle ABC \cong \triangle DEF$.
Proof:
We have $BF = EC$.
Adding $FC$ to both sides:
$BF + FC = EC + FC$
$\Rightarrow BC = EF$.
In right-angled triangles $ABC$ and $DEF$:
$BC = EF$ (Hypotenuse, proved above)
$BA = DE$ (Given)
$\angle A = \angle D = 90^\circ$ (Given)
$\therefore \triangle ABC \cong \triangle DEF$ (by RHS congruence rule).

questions.question: Q is a point on the side SR of a $\triangle PSR$ such that PQ = PR. Prove that PS > PQ.
questions.solution:
Given: $\triangle PSR$ with point $Q$ on $SR$ such that $PQ = PR$.
To prove: $PS > PQ$.
Proof:
In $\triangle PQR$, $PQ = PR$ (Given).
$\therefore \angle PQR = \angle PRQ$ (Angles opposite to equal sides are equal).
Consider $\triangle PSQ$. The exterior angle at vertex $Q$ is $\angle PQR$.
We know that an exterior angle of a triangle is greater than either of the interior opposite angles.
$\therefore \angle PQR > \angle PSQ$ (which is $\angle S$).
Since $\angle PQR = \angle PRQ$, we have $\angle PRQ > \angle S$.
In $\triangle PSR$, $\angle PRQ$ is the same as $\angle R$.
So, $\angle R > \angle S$.
In $\triangle PSR$, the side opposite to the greater angle is longer.
Side opposite $\angle R$ is $PS$. Side opposite $\angle S$ is $PR$.
$\therefore PS > PR$.
Since $PR = PQ$ (Given), we get $PS > PQ$.
Hence proved.

questions.question: S is any point on side QR of a $\triangle PQR$. Show that $PQ + QR + RP > 2PS$.
questions.solution:
Given: $S$ is a point on $QR$ of $\triangle PQR$.
To prove: $PQ + QR + RP > 2PS$.
Proof:
In $\triangle PQS$, sum of two sides is greater than the third side.
$\therefore PQ + QS > PS$ ... (1)
In $\triangle PRS$, sum of two sides is greater than the third side.
$\therefore PR + RS > PS$ ... (2)
Adding (1) and (2):
$(PQ + QS) + (PR + RS) > PS + PS$
$\Rightarrow PQ + PR + (QS + RS) > 2PS$
$\Rightarrow PQ + PR + QR > 2PS$
Hence proved.

questions.question: D is any point on side AC of a $\triangle ABC$ with $AB = AC$. Show that $CD < BD$.
questions.solution:
Given: $\triangle ABC$ with $AB = AC$ and $D$ is a point on $AC$.
To prove: $CD < BD$.
Proof:
In $\triangle ABC$, $AB = AC$ (Given).
$\therefore \angle ABC = \angle ACB$ (Angles opposite to equal sides are equal).
Since $D$ is a point on $AC$, $\angle DBC$ is a part of $\angle ABC$.
$\therefore \angle DBC < \angle ABC$.
Since $\angle ABC = \angle ACB$, we have $\angle DBC < \angle ACB$.
In $\triangle BDC$, side opposite to larger angle is longer.
Side opposite $\angle ACB$ (which is $\angle DCB$) is $BD$.
Side opposite $\angle DBC$ is $CD$.
Since $\angle DCB > \angle DBC$, we have $BD > CD$.
$\Rightarrow CD < BD$.
Hence proved.

questions.question: In Fig. 7.7, l || m and M is the mid-point of a line segment AB. Show that M is also the mid-point of any line segment CD, having its end-points on l and m, respectively.
questions.solution:
Given: $l \parallel m$, $M$ is midpoint of $AB$. $CD$ is a line segment with $C$ on $l$ and $D$ on $m$ passing through $M$.
To prove: $M$ is midpoint of $CD$.
Proof:
Consider $\triangle AMC$ and $\triangle BMD$.
$\angle MAC = \angle MBD$ (Alternate interior angles, since $AC \parallel BD$ as $l \parallel m$)
$AM = BM$ (Given $M$ is midpoint of $AB$)
$\angle AMC = \angle BMD$ (Vertically opposite angles)
$\therefore \triangle AMC \cong \triangle BMD$ (by ASA congruence rule).
$\Rightarrow CM = DM$ (by CPCT).
Therefore, $M$ is the midpoint of $CD$.

questions.question: Bisectors of the angles B and C of an isosceles triangle with $AB = AC$ intersect each other at O. BO is produced to a point M. Prove that $\angle MOC = \angle ABC$.
questions.solution:
Given: $\triangle ABC$ with $AB = AC$. $OB$ and $OC$ bisect $\angle B$ and $\angle C$ respectively. $BO$ is produced to $M$.
To prove: $\angle MOC = \angle ABC$.
Proof:
Since $AB = AC$, $\angle ABC = \angle ACB$.
Since $OB$ and $OC$ are bisectors, $\angle OBC = \frac{1}{2}\angle ABC$ and $\angle OCB = \frac{1}{2}\angle ACB$.
$\therefore \angle OBC = \angle OCB$.
In $\triangle OBC$, exterior angle $\angle MOC$ is equal to sum of interior opposite angles.
$\angle MOC = \angle OBC + \angle OCB$.
$\angle MOC = \frac{1}{2}\angle ABC + \frac{1}{2}\angle ABC = \angle ABC$.
Hence proved.

questions.question: Bisectors of the angles B and C of an isosceles triangle ABC with $AB = AC$ intersect each other at O. Show that the external angle adjacent to $\angle ABC$ is equal to $\angle BOC$.
questions.solution:
Given: $\triangle ABC$ with $AB = AC$. $OB$ and $OC$ bisect $\angle B$ and $\angle C$.
To prove: External angle at $B$ equals $\angle BOC$.
Proof:
Let $\angle ABC = \angle ACB = 2x$.
Then $\angle OBC = \angle OCB = x$.
In $\triangle OBC$, $\angle BOC = 180^\circ - (x + x) = 180^\circ - 2x$.
The external angle adjacent to $\angle ABC$ is $180^\circ - \angle ABC = 180^\circ - 2x$.
$\therefore$ External angle at $B = \angle BOC$.
Hence proved.

questions.question: In Fig. 7.8, AD is the bisector of $\angle BAC$. Prove that $AB > BD$.
questions.solution:
Given: $AD$ bisects $\angle BAC$.
To prove: $AB > BD$.
Proof:
In $\triangle ADC$, exterior angle $\angle ADB = \angle DAC + \angle C$.
Since $AD$ bisects $\angle A$, $\angle DAC = \angle BAD$.
$\therefore \angle ADB = \angle BAD + \angle C$.
This implies $\angle ADB > \angle BAD$.
In $\triangle ABD$, side opposite to greater angle is longer.
Side opposite $\angle ADB$ is $AB$.
Side opposite $\angle BAD$ is $BD$.
$\therefore AB > BD$.
Hence proved.
